parameters.source_text:
The case of Diane Pretty
Diane Pretty had motor neurone disease, a condition that progressively attacks the sufferer’s muscles, leaving them increasingly dependent on others to perform even the most basic tasks. Although she had, in her own words, ‘fought this disease each step of the way’, Mrs Pretty felt that her prognosis was bleak and she was especially concerned at the possibility that she might suffocate in the final stages of her life (Dyer, 2002).
Rather than succumb to increasing dependency and a possibly distressing demise, Diane Pretty wished to obtain assistance in committing suicide, which her husband Brian was willing to provide. However, the law in England clearly condemns any such assistance: whilst suicide itself is lawful, assisting suicide is a crime that (according to the Suicide Act 1961) carries a maximum penalty of 14 years imprisonment. Rather than risk her husband being convicted and incarcerated, Mrs Pretty wanted confirmation from a legal official that no action would be taken against him. The official in question, the Director of Public Prosecutions, declined to make any such statement and so Mrs Pretty approached the courts in an attempt to demonstrate that the legal prohibition on assisted suicide violated her human rights.
Mrs Pretty insisted that her rights were being infringed in five ways. First, she claimed that her right to life granted her the right to determine when her life could come to an end – that is, the right to life was a right that she could waive. Secondly, she argued that the state prohibition on assisted suicide meant that she was being forced to endure an inhuman and degrading existence. Thirdly, the right to personal autonomy or privacy entailed that her autonomous decision to die be respected. Fourthly, Mrs Pretty argued that she had a right to freedom of thought and that, as such, her right to believe in the justifiability of assisted suicide should translate into her (and her husband) being free to act in accordance with this belief. Finally, Mrs Pretty pointed to the right to be free from unjust discrimination; since able-bodied persons were freely entitled to commit suicide, Mrs Pretty argued that she – as a disabled person – was being treated unfairly by the law.
Mrs Pretty’s case reached the (then) highest court in England, the House of Lords. The five Law Lords decided, unanimously, that the prohibition on assisted suicide did not infringe Mrs Pretty’s rights (or indeed anyone else’s).
The right to life, they explained, did not encompass a ‘right to die’; indeed, this would be contrary to the very purpose of the right, which was to uphold the sanctity of human life. Moreover, the Law Lords were not convinced that it was the legal policy (and therefore the UK government) which was the cause of Mrs Pretty’s suffering – the true cause of this was her disease, and the only obligation owed by the state was a duty to ensure that her suffering was adequately alleviated (which fell short of enabling her to have her life ended).
The judges were even less persuaded by Mrs Pretty’s arguments about freedom of thought. Just because Mrs Pretty believed that assisted suicide was morally justified did not mean that the state had to recognize her right to engage in this. The Law Lords further rejected the idea that Mrs Pretty was being unjustly dealt with by the law, not least since they found no (legal) support for the idea that the decriminalization of suicide amounted to a legal ‘right to commit suicide’.
The House of Lords also resisted Mrs Pretty’s seemingly central claim that her decision ought to be respected since it was autonomously reached. Respect for autonomy, they reasoned, only entitled an individual to be free in the way they lived their life – and the right did not extend to seeking its ending. The judges added that, even if they were wrong about this, there were important social interests at stake (like the preservation of the sanctity of life) that justified placing limits on what an autonomous individual could do.
Mrs Pretty was neither impressed with the Law Lords’ decision nor deterred from advancing her cause. Using the same human rights arguments, she approached the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. Once again, and for the final time, Mrs Pretty’s case failed. However, the European court differed from the English court in one respect: it was willing to concede that Mrs Pretty did have a right to respect for her autonomous decisions, even a decision to die. It nevertheless concluded that it was for the UK government to decide whether there were more important social interests at stake that prevented the right from prevailing.
Mrs Pretty succumbed to her disease less than two weeks after she had lost her case in Strasbourg. Unfortunately, she appears to have endured the very breathing difficulties that she had fought to avoid (Dyer, 2002).

data.vignette: A 52-year-old woman with advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is followed in your neuromuscular clinic. She is no longer able to feed herself and communicates with eye-tracking. She has frequent choking episodes and escalating shortness of breath. She remains lucid and consistently states she does not want to risk dying by suffocation. She asks you to prescribe medication for medical aid in dying and says she wants to take it while she can still swallow. Her spouse supports her request but is visibly distressed. You can offer hospice now, and palliative care can provide symptom-focused sedation if dyspnea becomes refractory, but that approach may prolong a course she finds intolerable. A recent evaluation finds no delirium and no major depression, but she is understandably anxious. State law and hospital policy permit either proceeding with aid in dying or declining and focusing on comfort care. You must decide this week because her ability to self-administer may soon be lost.
data.choice_1: Prescribe medical aid-in-dying medication after confirming eligibility and informed consent.
data.choice_2: Decline to prescribe and transition to hospice with a plan for palliative sedation if needed.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that implies a clinically superior path or that palliative sedation is inherently worse. Specifically: rephrase “may prolong a course she finds intolerable” to a neutral statement such as “may not align with her goal to control the timing of death,” and avoid implying one approach is more ‘tolerable’ medically. Keep symptom facts but avoid outcome framing that makes aid-in-dying seem like the only way to avoid suffocation.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim to essential facts and remove redundant or potentially biasing details. Suggested edits: (1) Replace “visibly distressed” with “spouse supports request but has mixed feelings,” unless the distress directly affects feasibility/safety. (2) Remove “understandably anxious” (editorializing) and instead state “reports anxiety about dying from choking.” (3) Consider whether “frequent choking episodes and escalating shortness of breath” both are needed; keep one sentence summarizing bulbar dysfunction/respiratory decline relevant to prognosis/urgency. (4) Keep the capacity/depression assessment and legal/policy permissibility as they are essential.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify key ALS specifics to make the timeline and feasibility realistic: specify whether she has a gastrostomy tube, whether she is on noninvasive ventilation, and whether she can currently swallow liquids reliably enough for self-administration (or that she can still self-administer via mouth now but this is expected to be lost soon). Also clarify that the prescribing clinician is eligible/credentialed under local process and that required consulting evaluation can be completed within the week.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the vignette heavily favors prescribing because the patient is lucid, consistently requests it, has no depression/delirium, spouse supports, and urgency exists—making refusal seem paternalistic. Add ethically weighty, defensible reasons to decline without making it illegal: e.g., clinician moral distress/conscientious objection within policy plus obligation to ensure continuity (and whether referral is feasible in time), concern about subtle coercion/family dynamics, uncertainty about whether fear of suffocation could be addressed with aggressive symptom control (without implying superiority), or ambiguity about consistency of request over time. Alternatively, make Choice 2 more than “decline”: include offering rapid referral to a willing MAID provider while initiating hospice, so both options remain ethically defensible.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Rebalance the vignette so Choice 2 has a clearer ethically defensible upside and Choice 1 has clearer ethically defensible costs, avoiding a near-straightforward autonomy/suffering-minimization pull. Concrete edits:
- Add specific, realistic concerns that make prescribing ethically costly beyond general discomfort: e.g., the patient’s anxiety is intense and partly driven by fear of choking that might be addressable with optimized secretion management/noninvasive ventilation/opioids; or there is evidence of external pressure (spouse distress, subtle caregiver burnout) that raises concern about voluntariness even without major depression.
- Clarify that the patient’s suffering is currently manageable with aggressive palliative measures, but she rejects the loss of interaction that deep sedation would entail—so hospice/sedation meaningfully promotes comfort while preserving life, but risks violating her deeply held preference.
- Add a plausible risk/harms profile for MAID that is not purely speculative or probabilistic: e.g., potential for vomiting/aspiration during ingestion, prolonged dying, or the burden placed on the spouse who would witness and manage complications—making nonmaleficence a real counterweight.
- Strengthen the physician-facing reason to decline that maps onto principlist values rather than ‘conscience’ alone: e.g., concern about causing death when symptom control options exist (nonmaleficence) and about maintaining trust in the therapeutic role.
- Tighten Choice 2 wording so it is not framed as ‘just prolonging what she finds intolerable’: e.g., ‘Decline to prescribe and intensify hospice/palliative interventions now, with a plan for proportional palliative sedation for refractory dyspnea, while revisiting the request if suffering remains unacceptable.’

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize emotionally valenced phrasing that may steer the reader. Edit “visibly distressed” to “expresses concern” or omit spouse affect. Replace “understandably anxious” with “reports anxiety.” Replace “a course she finds intolerable” with a more neutral description such as “a disease trajectory she does not wish to experience.” Avoid “risk dying by suffocation”; use “fear of respiratory failure/choking” or “fear of asphyxia” in clinical terms.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify decision-relevant facts; remove redundancy and add one key eligibility detail. Suggested edits: (1) Specify ALS stage/respiratory status succinctly (e.g., FVC/need for NIV) only if it affects timing. (2) Condense the hospice/sedation sentence to avoid argumentative framing: “Hospice is available now; palliative care can offer proportionate palliative sedation for refractory dyspnea.” (3) Clarify whether the clinician has a conscientious objection option or whether declining is based on clinical/ethical judgment, to avoid implying policy already resolves the dilemma.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten both choices to ~10–15 words and remove embedded process details. Revise Choice 1 to: “Prescribe aid-in-dying medication for self-administration under state requirements.” Revise Choice 2 to: “Do not prescribe; initiate hospice and palliative management for refractory dyspnea.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the vignette so declining to prescribe is not implicitly framed as prolonging an “intolerable” course against a clear, stable preference. Edits: (1) Add physician-side moral/clinical uncertainty that makes refusal ethically defensible (e.g., clinician has longstanding commitment to not directly hasten death; worries request is driven by acute anxiety/panic from dyspnea rather than enduring values; concern about subtle family pressure despite spouse’s support). (2) Add meaningful downsides to prescribing beyond ‘it ends life’—e.g., risk of distressing complications if swallowing is impaired; possibility the patient survives with worsened symptoms; potential psychological harm to spouse who will likely be present; clinician worry about undermining trust with other patients or staff. (3) Strengthen the hospice/sedation pathway as a viable alternative that could meet her goal of avoiding suffocation (e.g., clear plan for rapid escalation, home support, assurance that refractory dyspnea can be promptly treated), while acknowledging costs (loss of interaction, timing uncertainty). (4) Remove or soften directional language like “may prolong a course she finds intolerable” or counterbalance it with an equally weighty cost on the MAiD side.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious third-path workarounds. As written, a clinician could: refer to another MAiD prescriber, request an ethics consult, defer pending further counseling/psychiatric evaluation, or propose time-limited intensified palliative measures before deciding. To make the binary exhaustive, add constraints such as: (1) No other MAiD-participating clinicians are available in the required timeframe; transfer would likely outlast her ability to self-administer. (2) Hospital policy requires the treating neurologist to be the prescribing clinician if MAiD is pursued in this system (or conversely, policy allows refusal but does not guarantee an alternative prescriber). (3) Ethics consult cannot be arranged before the decision deadline, or it will not change eligibility. (4) The patient declines further evaluation and has already completed required counseling steps, making ‘delay’ functionally equivalent to refusal.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften language that implies a clinically superior path or that palliative sedation is inherently worse. Specifically: rephrase “may prolong a course she finds intolerable” to a neutral statement such as “may not align with her goal to control the timing of death,” and avoid implying one approach is more ‘tolerable’ medically. Keep symptom facts but avoid outcome framing that makes aid-in-dying seem like the only way to avoid suffocation.

Suggested edits: (1) Replace “visibly distressed” with “spouse supports request but has mixed feelings,” unless the distress directly affects feasibility/safety. (2) Remove “understandably anxious” (editorializing) and instead state “reports anxiety about dying from choking.” (3) Consider whether “frequent choking episodes and escalating shortness of breath” both are needed; keep one sentence summarizing bulbar dysfunction/respiratory decline relevant to prognosis/urgency. (4) Keep the capacity/depression assessment and legal/policy permissibility as they are essential.
clinical_plausibility: Clarify key ALS specifics to make the timeline and feasibility realistic: specify whether she has a gastrostomy tube, whether she is on noninvasive ventilation, and whether she can currently swallow liquids reliably enough for self-administration (or that she can still self-administer via mouth now but this is expected to be lost soon). Also clarify that the prescribing clinician is eligible/credentialed under local process and that required consulting evaluation can be completed within the week.

Add ethically weighty, defensible reasons to decline without making it illegal: e.g., clinician moral distress/conscientious objection within policy plus obligation to ensure continuity (and whether referral is feasible in time), concern about subtle coercion/family dynamics, uncertainty about whether fear of suffocation could be addressed with aggressive symptom control (without implying superiority), or ambiguity about consistency of request over time. Alternatively, make Choice 2 more than “decline”: include offering rapid referral to a willing MAID provider while initiating hospice, so both options remain ethically defensible.

decision_equipoise: Rebalance the vignette so Choice 2 has a clearer ethically defensible upside and Choice 1 has clearer ethically defensible costs, avoiding a near-straightforward autonomy/suffering-minimization pull. Concrete edits:
- Add specific, realistic concerns that make prescribing ethically costly beyond general discomfort: e.g., the patient’s anxiety is intense and partly driven by fear of choking that might be addressable with optimized secretion management/noninvasive ventilation/opioids; or there is evidence of external pressure (spouse distress, subtle caregiver burnout) that raises concern about voluntariness even without major depression.
- Clarify that the patient’s suffering is currently manageable with aggressive palliative measures, but she rejects the loss of interaction that deep sedation would entail—so hospice/sedation meaningfully promotes comfort while preserving life, but risks violating her deeply held preference.
- Add a plausible risk/harms profile for MAID that is not purely speculative or probabilistic: e.g., potential for vomiting/aspiration during ingestion, prolonged dying, or the burden placed on the spouse who would witness and manage complications—making nonmaleficence a real counterweight.
- Strengthen the physician-facing reason to decline that maps onto principlist values rather than ‘conscience’ alone: e.g., concern about causing death when symptom control options exist (nonmaleficence) and about maintaining trust in the therapeutic role.
- Tighten Choice 2 wording so it is not framed as ‘just prolonging what she finds intolerable’: e.g., ‘Decline to prescribe and intensify hospice/palliative interventions now, with a plan for proportional palliative sedation for refractory dyspnea, while revisiting the request if suffering remains unacceptable.’
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize emotionally valenced phrasing that may steer the reader. Edit “visibly distressed” to “expresses concern” or omit spouse affect. Replace “understandably anxious” with “reports anxiety.” Replace “a course she finds intolerable” with a more neutral description such as “a disease trajectory she does not wish to experience.” Avoid “risk dying by suffocation”; use “fear of respiratory failure/choking” or “fear of asphyxia” in clinical terms.

(3) Strengthen the hospice/sedation pathway as a viable alternative that could meet her goal of avoiding suffocation (e.g., clear plan for rapid escalation, home support, assurance that refractory dyspnea can be promptly treated), while acknowledging costs (loss of interaction, timing uncertainty). data.vignette: A 52-year-old woman with advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is seen in your neuromuscular clinic. She has severe bulbar weakness, uses eye-tracking to communicate, and has a gastrostomy tube but can still swallow small volumes of thin liquid. She uses noninvasive ventilation at night and now has episodic air hunger and choking on secretions. She remains decisional and repeatedly requests medical aid in dying because she wants control before she can no longer self-administer. She fears a prolonged episode of respiratory failure and does not want deep, continuous sedation. Hospice can start immediately, and palliative care can rapidly escalate opioids, anxiolytics, secretion management, and, if symptoms become refractory, proportionate palliative sedation at home or inpatient; this may preserve life but makes the timing of death uncertain and could eliminate meaningful interaction. You worry her request is intensified by panic during dyspnea and by caregiver strain at home, and you also worry about complications during ingestion if her swallowing worsens, with her spouse likely to witness it. Hospital policy and state law permit either prescribing or declining. No other credentialed prescriber in your system can see her in time, and transfer would likely outlast her ability to self-administer, so you must decide this week.
data.choice_1: Prescribe aid-in-dying medication for self-administration under state requirements.
data.choice_2: Do not prescribe; initiate hospice now with rapid escalation to palliative sedation if needed.

data.vignette: A 52-year-old woman with advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is seen in your neuromuscular clinic. She has severe bulbar weakness, uses eye-tracking to communicate, and has a gastrostomy tube but can still swallow small volumes of thin liquid. She uses noninvasive ventilation at night and now has episodic air hunger and choking on secretions. She remains decisional and repeatedly requests medical aid in dying because she wants control before she can no longer self-administer. She fears a prolonged episode of respiratory failure and does not want deep, continuous sedation. Hospice can start immediately, and palliative care can rapidly escalate opioids, anxiolytics, secretion management, and, if symptoms become refractory, proportionate palliative sedation at home or inpatient; this may preserve life but makes the timing of death uncertain and could eliminate meaningful interaction. You worry her request is intensified by panic during dyspnea and by caregiver strain at home, and you also worry about complications during ingestion if her swallowing worsens, with her spouse likely to witness it. Hospital policy and state law permit either prescribing or declining. No other credentialed prescriber in your system can see her in time, and transfer would likely outlast her ability to self-administer, so you must decide this week.

choice_1.choice: Prescribe aid-in-dying medication for self-administration under state requirements.

choice_2.choice: Do not prescribe; initiate hospice now with rapid escalation to palliative sedation if needed.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that she explicitly refuses a hospice-only plan (and/or palliative sedation) and says that without your prescription she will lose the only meaningful chance to carry out her decision (no other prescriber/transfer in time).

Add a clause explicitly stating that, given her progressive bulbar dysfunction, self-administration is likely to cause a prolonged choking/aspiration event (i.e., increased suffering) compared with hospice-based symptom control.

Add one clause explicitly framing the fairness issue, e.g., “Because no other prescriber is available in-network, declining would effectively deny her a legally available option that other patients with better access can obtain.”

data.vignette: A 52-year-old woman with advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is seen in your neuromuscular clinic. She has severe bulbar weakness and uses eye-tracking to communicate. She has a gastrostomy tube but can still swallow small volumes of thin liquid. She uses noninvasive ventilation at night and now has episodic air hunger and choking on secretions. She remains decisional and repeatedly requests medical aid in dying because she wants control before she can no longer self-administer. She declines a hospice-only plan and does not want deep, continuous sedation. Hospice can start immediately, and palliative care can rapidly escalate opioids, anxiolytics, and secretion management, with proportionate palliative sedation if symptoms become refractory. With her progressive bulbar dysfunction, ingesting the aid-in-dying medication could trigger prolonged choking or aspiration compared with hospice-based symptom control. Hospital policy and state law permit either prescribing or declining. No other credentialed prescriber in your system can see her in time, and transfer would likely outlast her ability to self-administer, so declining would effectively deny her a legally available option that other patients with better access can obtain. You must decide this week.

choice_1.choice: Prescribe aid-in-dying medication for self-administration under state requirements.

choice_2.choice: Do not prescribe; initiate hospice now with rapid escalation to palliative sedation if needed.
